articles.title: Hundreds of jobs on offer in Antarctica with enticing salaries
articles.author: 9News
articles.summary: Hundreds of jobs are on offer for Australians willing to work in Antarctica. Roles include electricians, carpenters, mechanics, chefs, speicialist in science, aviation and information technology. The pay is almost double what Australians earn doing the same job in Australia.

articles.title: Unseasonable temperatures set to seesaw for millions of Australians
articles.summary: Unseasonable temperatures set to seesaw for millions of Australians due to unseasonable weather in Australia's south-east and north-east.      Â   in the next few days. For more information, visit weather.gov.au.

articles.title: Aussies to bake while others freeze
articles.author: News Wire
articles.summary: Bureau of Meteorology forecasts temperatures to rise by up to 10C higher than the seasonal average. Melbourne is set to see a seesaw between highs and lows, with 21C forecast for Tuesday, 30C on Thursday, and then back down to 19C on Friday. Adelaide is forecast for a maximum of just 21C on Tuesday, rising to 29C on Wednesday, before falling back to 21C. Brisbane is expected to be more consistent, with a maximum 26C forecast on Tuesday and rising to 28C by Friday. Warm air from the Australian interior collides with cold fronts sweeping across the southeast.

articles.title: Outgoing Buller Mayor urges future leaders to continue Westport flood plan
articles.author: Anna Sargent of
articles.summary: Jamie Cleine cried as he told the Adaptation Futures Conference about the risk facing his flood-prone town of Westport. He called on future leaders to continue climate adaptation work to help protect his town from flooding. He is the outgoing mayor of Buller.

articles.title: Unseasonable temperatures set to seesaw for millions of Australians
articles.summary: Bureau of Meteorology forecasts temperatures to rise by up to 10C higher than the seasonal average. Melbourne is set to see a seesaw between highs and lows, with 21C forecast for Tuesday, 30C on Thursday, and then back down to 19C on Friday. Adelaide is forecast for a maximum of just 21C on Tuesday, rising to 29C on Wednesday, before falling back to 21C. Brisbane is expected to be more consistent, with a maximum 26C forecast on Tuesday and rising to 28C by Friday. Warm air from the Australian interior collides with cold fronts sweeping across the southeast.

articles.title: Temperature shock: Australian cities face 15C weather fluctuations
articles.summary: Bureau of Meteorology forecasts temperatures to rise by up to 10C higher than the seasonal average. Melbourne is set to seeaw between highs and lows, with 21C forecast for Tuesday, 30C on Thursday, and then back down to 19C on Friday. Adelaide is forecast for a maximum of just 21C on Tuesday, rising to 29C on Wednesday, before falling back to 21C. Hobart temperatures are expected to rise from 17C to 26C, while Canberra temperatures will likely rise from 22C to 27C by Thursday. Perth is expected to be hit by temperatures of 29C by Friday, while in the north, Darwin temperatures will stay in the 35C range

articles.title: Unseasonable temperatures set to seesaw for millions of Australians
articles.summary: Temperatures in Sydney are expected to rise by up to 10C higher than the seasonal average. Melbourne is forecast to seeaw between highs and lows, with 21C forecast for Tuesday, 30C on Thursday, and then back down to 19C on Friday. Adelaide is forecast for a maximum of just 21C on Tuesday, rising to 29C on Wednesday, before falling back to 21C. Brisbane is set to be more consistent, with a maximum 26C forecast on Tuesday and rising to 28C by Friday. The fluctuations come as warm air from the Australian interior collides with cold fronts sweeping across the southeast.

articles.title: Climate ‘tipping points' are being surpassed: researchers
articles.author: Rachel Frazin
articles.summary: Global Tipping Points report says that between 2023 and 2025, coral reefs saw their worst bleaching on record and that the estimated temperature 'tipping point' has been crossed. Ice sheets are also on their way to irreversible collapse. Antarctic sea ice may have a tipping point that could already be underway.

articles.title: Wrightsville Beach scarred with sand cliffs; access points remained closed
articles.author: Kamy Smelser
articles.summary: This weekend's storm left three to six feet of sand cliffs and escarpments behind at Wrightsville Beach. The town hopes to reopen the access points later this week. Macon Worth is a regular visitor to the beach and says it would take three or four years to wash away this much sand.

articles.title: Greenland Is Shrinking Slightly And Drifting Slowly Towards Northwest
articles.author: Eurasia Review
articles.summary: Greenland is being twisted, compressed, and stretched due to plate tectonics and movements in the bedrock. The entire island has shifted northwest over the past 20 years by about 2 cm per year. The movements are causing Greenland to both expand and contract horizontally. The effect is that Greenland's area is currently being 'stretched out' and becoming slightly larger in some regions, while others are being 'pulled together'. The new measurements are based on 58 GNSS stations (GPS) placed around Greenland.

articles.title: Nor'easter battering East Coast with damaging flooding and winds
articles.summary: Tropical weather in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans is causing dangerous conditions in the United States, Mexico and the Caribbean. It's also causing problems in the Pacific Ocean and in the North Atlantic Ocean. It could cause problems in Mexico, the U.S. and Caribbean.

articles.title: What La Niña update means for Aussie weather over spring and summer
articles.author: Joe Attanasio
articles.summary: La Niña is a weather phenomenon that brings cooler ocean temperatures in the Pacific. It is the counterpart to El Niño, which causes drier conditions. La Niña event is officially underway in the US, but not in Australia. The BoM uses slightly stricter criteria than the CPC.

articles.title: State Pact: Climate Action Beyond 4 Years
articles.summary: Europe is warming at an alarming rate and Spain is on the front lines. The European Central Bank estimates climate change will cost Spain €32 billion by the end of this decade. Spain's Vice President Sara Aagesen is pushing for a State Pact against the Climate Emergency, bringing together experts, institutions, unions, and companies. The Popular Party (PP) has refused to participate, dismissing the convention as 'propaganda'.

articles.title: Topsail Beach closes two beach accesses due to hazardous drop-offs
articles.author: WECT Staff
articles.summary: Beach accesses #19 and #20 in Topsail Beach are temporarily closed due to a large drop-off in the area. Crews are working to ensure the accesses are safe for the public, town officials say. The accesses will be reopened soon.

articles.title: Claim: We've Hit a Climate Change Tipping Point
articles.author: Eric Worrall
articles.summary: Global Tipping Points Report suggests the world's coral reefs are at risk of mass dieback. About 84 per cent of them have bleached in the fourth global bleaching event since January, 2023. The upper limit of the tipping point threshold for coral reefs is 1.5C.

articles.title: Report: Earth reached first climate tipping point with coral reef die-offs
articles.summary: Earth has reached its first climate change tipping point with the widespread death of coral reefs, according to a new report from the World Resources Institute. The report claims that the world has reached a new tipping point in terms of climate change and the death of the coral reefs.

articles.title: Climate tipping points sound scary, especially for ice sheets and oceans – here's why there's still room for optimism
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: East Antarctic ice sheet is not in immediate danger. In the Amazon, self-perpetuating feedback loops threaten the stability of the Earth's largest rain forest. By 2050, nearly half of the Amazon rain forest could face multiple stressors. The once-damp rainforest canopy could shift to a dry savanna for at least several centuries. The second Global Tipping Points Report suggests tropical reefs may have passed a tipping point that will wipe out all but isolated patches. Low-latitude reefs have the highest risk of tipping, with the upper threshold at 1.5 C.

articles.title: What is acid rain—and can it be prevented?
articles.summary: A cid rain is an environmental problem that affects forests, lakes, wildlife, buildings, and even human health around the world. It occurs when gases released by burning fossil fuels mix with water, oxygen, and other chemicals. This process creates acids that fall back to Earth as rain, snow, or dry particles. Over time, acid rain can harm ecosystems, corrode buildings and add costs to communities.

articles.title: Coral reef decline signals Earth's first climate tipping point, scientists warn
articles.author: Julia Musto
articles.summary: Earth has reached its first climate tipping point, according to the Global Tipping Points Report by 160 international researchers. Coral reefs, vital for a billion people and a quarter of marine life, are entering a 'new reality' of decline. The planet has already warmed 1.2C and is on track for 3.1C by 2100. Critical climate tipping points could occur with just 1-2 C of global warming.

articles.title: Labor waters down super tax plan
articles.author: Karen Barlow
articles.summary: Scarborough gas extraction could contribute 0.00039C to global heating, exposing 516,000 people globally to unprecedented heat and killing at least 480 people. Woodside claims the emissions associated with the project are negligible. Albanese government has approved 31 fossil fuel projects, with another 38 coal projects seeking approval.

articles.title: Human cost of Woodside gas field counted
articles.author: Karen Barlow
articles.summary: Scarborough gas extraction could contribute 0.00039C to global heating, exposing 516,000 people globally to unprecedented heat and killing at least 480 people. Woodside claims the emissions associated with the project are negligible. Albanese government has approved 31 fossil fuel projects, with another 38 coal projects seeking approval.

articles.title: Chris Martz Shares FRIGHTENING Reports About How Climate Change Threatens Humanity (Decades Ago)
articles.author: Doug P.
articles.summary: Bernie Sanders, Al Gore, Dan Rather and Chris Martz have warned about the dangers of climate change since the 1960s. The attempts to politically weaponize the weather and climate has been irritating and shameless since about the 60s.    If we don't stop digging up ancient carbon and burning it, 25% of Florida will be underwater in 25 years.

articles.title: City-edge broiler operation offered with ongoing supply contract
articles.author: Mark Phelps
articles.summary: A broiler operation with five, tunnel-ventilated sheds set on 10 hectares in the Brisbane suburb of Moggill is on the market. The farm has a total capacity of 165,240 birds per batch, with 5.8 batches a year on average. It is located within a 40-minute drive of the Brisbane CBD and about an hour an 1.1 hours from the Golden Cockerill processing plant at Mount Cotton. The operation is described as being easily managed by a full-time farm manager and an assistant manager.

articles.title: Unusual red rocks in Australia are rewriting the rules on exceptional fossil sites
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: McGraths Flat is one of Australia's most extraordinary fossil sites. It dates back between 11 million and 16 million years into the Miocene epoch. It is hidden beneath farmland in the central tablelands of New South Wales, Australia's central farming region.

articles.title: Moderate warming may not doom humid subtropical forests' carbon storage
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: A new study challenges the long-standing assumption that global warming will turn humid, as it did in the study of the study by the University of California, Los Angeles. It found that it will be more humid in the future, rather than warmer.

articles.title: Canada heat waves in 2025 tied to human-driven climate change
articles.author: Nathan Howes
articles.summary: This year's extreme weather events in Canada have been linked to human-caused climate change. Environment and Climate Change Canada (ECCC) established a rapid extreme weather event attribution system to compare today's climate with the pre-industrial state. The system shows that of the 10 heat waves in Canada this year, nine were made "much more likely" because of climate change, according to ECCC.

articles.title: From Fields to Kitchens, the Fight Against Extreme Heat Is a Fight for Workers' Lives
articles.author: Chris Ramsaroop
articles.summary: This summer, temperatures in North America broke records. Jeremiah, a greenhouse worker in Ontario's Seasonal Agricultural Worker program, had to be carried out on a cart after collapsing in the heat. Justicia for Migrant Workers (J4MW) organizer has been organizing migrant and food system workers for 25 years. According to the International Labour Organization, more than 2.4 billion people worldwide are exposed to workplace heat stress. In Ontario, the provincial government promised heat protections in 2023, but quietly killed them a year later.

articles.title: Modelling shows gas project emissions will cause hundreds of heat-related deaths
articles.author: Jo Lauder
articles.summary: Australian researchers have linked a fossil fuel project to climate impacts, modelling that Woodside's Scarborough project will cause 484 heat-related deaths in Europe. It's the first time a scientific paper has attributed the climate impacts of a specific Fossil Fuel Project to global warming. It also found that the incremental rise in global temperatures from that one project would result in an additional 16 million corals lost in every bleaching event on the Great Barrier Reef and expose an extra 516,000 people to unprecedented heat.

articles.title: IOM urges global investment in disaster resilience after record 46 million displaced
articles.author: Josiah St. Luce
articles.summary: This year's International Day for Disaster Risk Reduction (IDDRR) is being observed under the theme Fund Resilience, Not Disasters. Nearly 46 million people were displaced by disasters in 2024, the highest number ever recorded. Most governments dedicate less than one per cent of their budgets to risk reduction efforts.

articles.title: Planet's first catastrophic climate tipping point reached
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: The world's tropical coral reefs have almost certainly crossed a point of no return as oceans warm beyond a level most can survive. It is the first time scientists have declared that Earth has likely reached a so-called "tipping point" - a shift that could trigger massive and permanent changes in the natural world. The biggest and most intense coral bleaching episode ever witnessed has spread to more than 80 percent of the world's reefs.

articles.title: Top 5 coldest countries in the world
articles.author: Favour Osah
articles.summary: Antarctica is the coldest place on Earth, with average annual temperatures around -56.7°C (70°F) and the record for the lowest temperature ever recorded: -89.2°C (-128.6°F). Russia is massive and cold, while in places like Siberia winter can feel eternal. Canada's northern territories are infamous for their icy winters. Mongolia's capital, Ulaanbaatar, is coldest national capital in the world, with winter temperatures often below -40°C. Norway's Arctic regions, particularly the Svalbard archipelago, experience extreme cold.

articles.title: Clinic treats dozens of hawks since early August
articles.summary: The clinic has treated many birds injured along roadways since early August. Fall bird migration means an increase in migratory hawks showing up as patients this time of the year, according to the Alberta Institute for Wildlife Conservation (AICWC).

articles.title: Some climate ‘tipping points' already being crossed, researchers warn
articles.author: The Hill
articles.summary: Some irreversible climate harms are already happening to the planet, researchers warn ahead of this year's global climate summit. Between 2023 and 2025, coral reefs saw their worst, according to a new report. Even under the most optimistic emission scenarios, warm-water coral reefs are virtually certain to tip.

articles.title: Our Changing World: What happened when the pūteketeke's fame faded?
articles.summary: Richard Bowman counts the Australasian crested grebes at Lake Hayes monthly. The grebes were crowned Forest and Bird's 'Bird of the Century' in 2023. John Oliver started a campaign to promote the pūteketeke. The water quality in Lake Hayes has been affected by pollution.

articles.title: ActionAid Ghana Pushes for Climate Investment in Coastal Areas
articles.author: News Ghana
articles.summary: ActionAid Ghana has issued an urgent call for increased climate adaptation funding to safeguard the nation's vulnerable coastal communities. The organization has been actively addressing these challenges through a $2.7 million coastal resilience project launched earlier this year. The initiative targets 11 high-risk communities across Greater Accra and Volta regions. ActionAid's demand reflects broader concerns within Ghana's civil society about climate vulnerability.

articles.title: Coral reef bleaching at tipping point due to global warming
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: Scientists warn that coral reef ecosystems are dying out quicker than expected as global temperatures rise. The Global Tipping Points report by 160 researchers worldwide comes weeks before this year's COP30 climate summit. Caroline Malone reports on the report for CNN iReport.com.

articles.title: Meteorologist Calls Out ‘Settled' Climate Claims, Reveals Overlooked Atmospheric Dynamics
articles.author: Anthony J. Sadar
articles.summary: Changes that occur in the atmosphere occur in three dimensions. Academic and government studies delve into the dimensional complexity of the airy environment, but the study results are delivered and interpreted in a simplistic way. Many in the public, politicians, and news media conclude that the Earth's air temperature is rising to dangerous levels due to increasing levels of carbon dioxide, and without cessation of fossil fuel use, life on Earth will die.

articles.title: Southern Africa: Angola Urged to Adopt Mitigating Measures to Address Climate Change
articles.summary: Marcos Pinheiro is a Brazilian sustainability consultant. He presented a topic at the 1st Forum on Sustainable Financing and Carbon Transition in Luanda. He warned of the potential vulnerability of Angola despite its low greenhouse gas emissions. He said subsistence agriculture is the sector most at risk.

articles.title: How the colonization of the Americas cooled Earth's climate
articles.summary: The arrival of Europeans in the Americas in the late 15th century ushered in a dramatic chapter in world history. It also coincided with a climatic shift known as the Little Ice Age. This period of global cooling remains a subject of curiosity and study among historians, scientists, and environmental researchers.

articles.title: 'Our New Reality': Planet Reaches First Climate Tipping Point With Coral Reef Dieback
articles.author: Julia Conley
articles.summary: Global warming has already crossed the tipping point for coral reefs, according to the Global Tipping Points Report 2025. Global warming is 1.4°C above preindustrial levels. The worst bleaching event since 2023 affected 84% of the world's coral reefs. Without rapid cuts to greenhouse gas emissions, the upper threshold for coral reef temperature rise of 1.5°C is likely to be reached within 10 years.

articles.title: Photos: Dunes collapsed in North Myrtle Beach, SC due to storms
articles.author: Jason Lee
articles.summary: King tides and a Fall storm caused dunes to collapse in Cherry Grove section of North Myrtle Beach, SC on Monday, Oct. 13, 2025. A woman reads a book under a collapsed dune in the Cherry Grove part of the beach, where evidence of beach erosion can be seen.

articles.title: Psychological effects of climate change
articles.author: Editor'S Mail
articles.summary: The link between climate change and mental health is often overlooked. Monsoon-inspired floods killed hundreds of people and displaced millions this year. Climate-induced migration, food insecurity, and loss of livelihoods add to psychological distress. Farmers and labourers working in extreme weather conditions often experience eco-anxiety. Public awareness campaigns, counselling services, and community support programmes must be integrated into climate adaptation strategies.

articles.title: End of the world as we know it: Damning new report says Earth has reached its first climate ‘tipping point'
articles.author: Julia Musto
articles.summary: The Earth has reached its first climate tipping point, according to the latest Global Tipping Points Report. Coral reefs, on which about a billion people depend for food and livelihood, are now tipping into an irreversible decline. Global warming has already warmed the Earth by 1.2C since the Industrial Revolution and is expected to reach 3.1C (5.6F) by 2100. World leaders are meeting in Brazil next month for the UN climate summit.

articles.title: Earth's climate just crossed a line we can't ignore
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Humanity has reached the first Earth system tipping point, the widespread death of warm-water coral reefs, marking the beginning of irreversible planetary shifts, as global temperatures rise. The world has reached a tipping point for climate change, as coral reefs die.

articles.title: Some climate ‘tipping points' already being crossed, researchers warn
articles.author: Rachel Frazin
articles.summary: Coral reefs saw their worst bleaching on record between 2023 and 2025 and their temperature 'tipping point' has been crossed. Ice sheets are also on their way to irreversible collapse. Antarctic sea ice may have a tipping point that could already be underway. The report comes from an organization called Global Tipping Points made up of 160 researchers from 23 countries. It's being published about a month before the start of COP30, the global climate summit in Brazil.

articles.title: Company hopes to revive oyster industry with farm in the Glades. Here are 5 takeaways
articles.author: The Miami Herald
articles.summary: Florida's wild oyster reefs have been devastated by overharvesting, pollution and climate change, but there are still some living oysters in the state.    .   "There is still life in the oyster reef in Florida.

articles.title: Net-zero is a pipe dream: civilisation now faces an existential threat
articles.author: Dr Kevin E Trenberth
articles.summary: Yogi Berra once said that it's difficult to make good predictions about the future. In his own field of climate science, he says that humans are changing the climate owing to changes in the composition of the atmosphere, mainly increases in carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels and other human activities. According to him, the biggest impacts on society will be through water because of increasing demand and the effects of climate change.

articles.title: ‘Go green or miss investment'
articles.author: Shawn Cumberbatch
articles.summary: Shania Taylor is an economic analyst in First Citizens' economic research unit. She wrote a commentary titled Green Or Gone: Climate Risk And Investment Flows In The Caribbean. She notes that for the Caribbean, climate vulnerability is now a defining factor in investment flows. Caribbean countries must go green or risk being gone from the investment map.

articles.title: Insurance seen closing finance gap as climate risks threaten food supply
articles.author: Modestus Anaesoronye
articles.summary: Experts in the West African sub-region have identified the critical role of insurance in closing finance gap towards tacking climate change risks. Olusegun Omosehin, commissioner for Insurance/CEO, National Insurance Commission said climate change is rewriting the narrative of our region. Uzoka Anite, minister of State for Finance, Federal Republic of Nigeria, said the same storms that affect Nigeria affect Ghana, Sierra Leone, Liberia, and The Gambia.

articles.title: Angola Reaffirms Commitment to Disaster Risk Reduction
articles.summary: Francisco Furtado reaffirmed Angola's commitment to implementing the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction and the UN's 2030 Agenda. The conference focused on Sustainable Development Goal 13 (SDG), which calls for urgent action to combat the impacts of climate change. The minister highlighted the government's investments in important infrastructure, such as the Cafu Canal and the Ndue and Calucuve Dams.

articles.title: La Niña returns, increasing risk of flooding and extreme weather
articles.author: Merit Designs Consulting Group
articles.summary: The La Niña weather phenomenon has returned and experts warn it will bring heavy rains, flooding and a notable drop in temperatures across much of the Dominican Republic in the coming months. The phenomenon occurs when equatorial Pacific waters cool more than usual, altering wind patterns and atmospheric circulation. The risk of storms and hurricanes remains.

articles.title: Spicer will discuss protecting the environment at Oct. 21 Rotary meeting
articles.summary: Dave Spicer will discuss 'Climate Crisis is Real and What Rotarians are Doing' at the Rotary Club of Mercer Island's meeting on Oct. 21 at the Mercer Island Community and Event Center, 8236 SE 24th St. The main meeting begins at 12:30 p.m. and the socializing is from noon to 12.30. A catered lunch is available for $25 and attendees can bring their own meal.

articles.title: NSW Daylight Saving Time 2025: Everything You Need to Know
articles.author: Annisa Lisya Bazlina
articles.summary: Daylight saving time is returning to New South Wales this weekend. Clocks will change on Sunday, October 5, at 2:00 a.m. (AEST), when they move forward one hour. In 2026, daylight saving time ends on the first Sunday in April.

articles.title: More than 70,000 pink-footed geese arrive in Scotland after 800-mile journey
articles.author: Victoria Pease
articles.summary: 70,000 geese have arrived in Montrose Basin in Angus for the winter months. The majority of them will stay until January and then continue their migration south. The site is celebrating its 30th anniversary. The visitor centre held a special GooseFest and local schoolchildren took part in Pink Foot Friday.

articles.title: Indore's Exclusive Climate Change
articles.summary: The days are getting hotter and nights are also hot in Indore. The climate changed affect not only Indore but also the world. We need to plant trees and less pollution to bring back the memories of the past and bring back nature and the memories too.

articles.title: World's coral reefs crossing survival limit: Global experts
articles.author: Nick Perry
articles.summary: It is the first time scientists have declared that Earth has likely reached a so-called 'tipping point' for tropical coral reefs. Global warming poses the greatest threat to these vibrant ecosystems. Most coral reefs would die at warming of 1.5C above pre-industrial levels. Since 2023, there has been unprecedented coral mortality on a global scale.

articles.title: Earth Passes First Climate Tipping Point, Scientists Warn Planet Faces 'New Reality'
articles.author: Chris Spiker
articles.summary: Global Tipping Points released its 2025 report on Sunday, Oct. 12. The report was produced by 160 scientists from 23 countries. It was financially backed by Amazon owner Jeff Bezos' environmental charity. It warns that global warming will soon exceed 1.5 degrees Celsius. Warm-water coral reefs are the first ecosystem to pass its climate tipping point. Polar ice sheets and Amazon rainforests are also in danger of collapse. Without immediate action, the report says global temperatures could exceed two degrees Celsius before 2100.

articles.title: Banks retreat from climate change commitments – but it's business more than politics –
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: Death of world's coral reefs a 'tipping point' in climate-driven ecosystem collapse', scientists say
articles.author: Alison Withers
articles.summary: Global warming is crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected. The world's coral reefs are in an irreversible die-off. The Amazon rainforest system is at risk of collapsing once the average global temperature warms beyond just 1.5C. The last two years were Earth's warmest on record, with marine heatwaves that stressed coral reefs to the point of bleaching.

articles.title: Alaska in Peril: Typhoon Halong's Devastating Impact
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Typhoon Halong left western Alaska in turmoil. Over 30 people were rescued, but three people are still missing. The villages of Kipnuk and Kwigillingok faced the brunt of the storm, with reports of homes being swept away. On the East Coast, a nor'easter caused significant coastal flooding from Virginia to New Jersey.

articles.title: Caspian Sea faces alarming decline in water levels and biodiversity
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: The Caspian Sea's water levels are declining due to climate change, dam construction along the Volga River, regional energy extraction, and heavy maritime traffic. The sea's water level has dropped significantly over the past decade, leading to a sharp decrease in biodiversity. About 2,000 dead seals were found on Kazakhstan's shores three years ago, and another 2,500 washed ashore on the Russian side. Kazakh President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev has warned that the sea's rapid retreat is no longer a regional issue but a global environmental alarm.

articles.title: Last month was the third-hottest September on RECORD - with average global temperatures hitting a balmy 16.11°C
articles.author: JONATHAN CHADWICK
articles.summary: Last month was the third-warmest September on record, according to EU's Copernicus Climate Change Service. Global average air temperature was 16.11°C (60.99°F), which is 0.66°C above the 1991-2020 average for September. It was 1.47°C higher than the 1850-1900 average for outside Europe and 1.3°C warmer than the pre-industrial average. The 12-month average temperature from October 2024 to September 2025 was 0.63°C  (1.13°F) above the pre‑industrial level.

articles.title: Earth has just reached its first catastrophic climate tipping point
articles.author: Liam Gilliver
articles.summary: Planet Earth is at its first-ever climate tipping point. Global warming has already caused widespread damage to warm-water coral reefs and the worst bleaching event on record from 2023 to 2025. The report calls for 'immediate' action from leaders at COP30 and policymakers worldwide. The Paris Agreement's climate goals are not enough.

articles.title: Rare Florida butterflies reflect impact of climate change
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: There are many endangered and declining pollinator species in South Florida. The Miami blue butterfly population has dropped by 99 percent since 1992. There is less than 2 percent of Pine Rockland left outside Everglades National Park. Climate change and rising sea levels are also affecting pollinators.

articles.title: CARICOM Gathers in Saint Lucia for Crucial Second Preparatory Meeting for COP30
articles.summary: Region Deepens Coordination Ahead of Global Climate Summit in Belem, Brazil. CARICOM leaders convened in Saint Lucia from October 7-10, 2025 for the Second Regional Preparatory Meeting for the 30th Conference of the Parties (COP30) to the UNFCCC.

articles.title: Edinburgh could see temperatures of 'minus 30' as climate tipping point reached
articles.author: Rebecca Speare-Cole
articles.summary: Edinburgh could see temperatures of minus 30 in the future according to a new report into global warming. Warm-water coral reefs are already passing their thermal tipping point. The Amazon rainforest could pass its tipping point before the world hits 2C warming. Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) faces collapse sooner than previously thought.

articles.title: Mum's anger as school trip costs more than holiday in Gran Canaria
articles.author: Neil Shaw
articles.summary: The nine-night trip to Kenya, East Africa offered by Carla Hoskins' son's school costs £2,186 for October 2026. It includes return flights, a work placement at a Kenyan primary school, and some excursions including a safari trip. Parents are expected to pay for the trip in three instalments, around £700 per payment. Carla and her family went to Gran Canaria last year for £1,800.

articles.title: We surveyed British MPs - most don't know how urgent climate action is
articles.author: John Kenny
articles.summary: Greenhouse gas emissions had to peak no later than 2025 to keep global warming below 1.5C, according to the IPCC report. Yet when the report was published a few years ago, greenhouse gas emissions didn't peak until 2025 as was predicted by the IPCC.

articles.title: Study: Annual climate losses rise 10-fold this century to $1.4tr last year
articles.author: Holly Roach
articles.summary: The physical impacts of climate change cost the global economy at least $1.4tr last year and have risen 10-fold since the turn of the century, according to a new analysis from BloombergNEF (BNEF).    ...

articles.title: Inaugural Climate Action Week Underway In Clare
articles.summary: Clare County Council is hosting its first ever Climate Action Week this week. There will be beach cleans in Lahinch, energy cafés in Kilrush and Ennis, biodiversity workshops and the screening of the film 'Birdsong' about one man's journey to record the bird call of every species in Ireland.

articles.title: Local Governments Worked Hard to Hedge Against Climate Disaster. Florida Leaders Bigfooted Them.
articles.author: Amy Green
articles.summary: Manatee County commissioners were threatened with removal from office for considering two measures to enhance disaster resilience in this fast-growing county on Florida's Gulf Coast. Last year, the county weathered three hurricanes: Debby, Helene and Milton. The measures had been in the works for a long time. Now the commissioners were in violation of a new state law that took effect July 1, SB 180. 25 local governments from across the state joined to sue the DeSantis administration over SB 180, which the governor signed into law in June.

articles.title: Each Fossil Fuel Project Linked To Additional Global Warming
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Scarborough gas project in Northwest Australia is estimated to lead to an increase of 0.00039°C in global temperature from 876 million tonnes of CO2 emissions. This degree of warming could expose over half a million people to unprecedented extreme heat. 16 million corals in the Great Barrier Reef would be lost in more frequent mass bleaching events and hundreds of deaths due to extreme heat in Europe alone. The Scarborough project's emissions are expected to comprise almost half of Australia's entire annual CO2 budget by 2049.

articles.title: Emissions linked to Woodside's Scarborough gas project could lead to at least 480 deaths, research suggests
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: $16.5bn project could expose more than half a million people to unprecedented heat, according to scientists' assessment.       .   "The project's climate impact is estimated to be $16bn and could expose people to heat.

articles.title: New Australian fossil fuel site could have major impact on people and the planet
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: A new fossil fuel site approved for development off Western Australia's coast is estimated to contribute 876 million tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions over the course of its lifetime. The majority of Australia's fossil fuel projects describe their anticipated greenhouse gas outputs as 'negligible' in the context of global emissions.

articles.title: Why is the 'dirty side' of a hurricane dangerous?
articles.summary: According to the Environmental Defense Fund, the most damaging hurricanes in the United States are three times more frequent than 100 years ago and the proportion of major hurricanes in Atlantic Ocean has doubled since 1980. There are many components to a hurricane, including the "dirty side" and the "clean side," with the dirty side being more dangerous.

articles.title: Heatwaves overwhelm nature's mechanisms to cope with wildfires
articles.author: Alex Reis
articles.summary: Extreme conditions increase the risk of wildfire incidents, according to a study published in the journal Communications Earth and Environment. Heatwaves lead to unseasonal drying of vegetation, bypassing natural ecological processes that limit the spread of wildfires. Future extreme heat events will increase the severity of wildfires in the UK due to this unseasonable drying effect.

articles.title: World Surpasses Its First Climate Tipping Point
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Global Tipping Points Report 2025 was released today, October 13, 2025. It is based on the current global warming of about 1.4°C and assumes that the global average temperature will increase by 1.5°C within the next few years. The report is published in time for the 30th World Climate Conference in Belém, Brazil.

articles.title: ‘Cosy and comforting': why The Fellowship of the Ring is my feelgood movie
articles.author: The Observer
articles.summary: When the autumn mists descend and the trees turn from leafy green to russet brown, some people defrost Gilmore Girls. I defrost Gimli son of Glóin (and the lads). The world needs saving again and I know just the nine capable sets of people.

articles.title: Planet Hits First Climate Tipping Point: Coral Reefs Face Widespread Collapse
articles.author: Web
articles.summary: Global Tipping Points report was compiled by 160 scientists from 87 institutions across 23 countries and led by the University of Exeter. Coral reefs, which support roughly a quarter of all marine species, are already under severe stress. Since January 2023, the world has been experiencing the fourth and most intense global bleaching event affecting over 80% of reefs across more than 80 countries. The report highlights that other ecological tipping points are also approaching, including the dieback of the Amazon rainforest, the collapse of key ocean currents and the accelerated loss of ice sheets in Greenland and West Antarctica.

articles.title: ‘No food, no business': Kenyan women reveal hidden links between climate change and mental health
articles.author: Craig Saueurs
articles.summary: Extreme heat, failed rains and unpredictable seasons are taking a psychological toll in rural Kenya. The Aga Khan University's Brain and Mind Institute conducted a survey of 15,000 women in rural farming communities in Kilifi County to study the link between climate change and mental health issues.

articles.title: How climate change is affecting Kenya's mental health
articles.author: Craig Saueurs
articles.summary: Extreme heat, failed rains and unpredictable seasons are taking a psychological toll in rural Kenya. The Aga Khan University's Brain and Mind Institute conducted a survey of 15,000 women in rural farming communities in Kilifi County to study the link between climate change and mental health issues.

articles.title: National report calls for urgent action to protect coastlines
articles.author: Victoria Budiono
articles.summary: A new report from the Surfrider Foundation highlights Oahu's North Shore Coastal Resilience Working Group as an example of how communities can take the lead in confronting climate change. The report describes the region as an 'erosion hot spot,' with 73% of beaches already chronically eroding and more than 90% projected to be by 2050.

articles.title: The planet has entered a ‘new reality' as it hits its first climate tipping point, report finds
articles.author: Laura Paddison
articles.summary: Warm water corals are the first in a series of climate tipping points. Since 2023, the world's reefs have been enduring the worst mass bleaching event on record as oceans reach record high temperatures. Coral reefs are an essential habitat for marine species, vital for food security, contribute trillions to the global economy and buffer coastal areas from storms. Global warming is all but certain to breach the globally agreed goal of limiting warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: The planet has entered a ‘new reality' as it hits its first climate tipping point, landmark report finds
articles.author: Laura Paddison
articles.summary: Warm water corals are the first in a series of climate tipping points. Since 2023, the world's reefs have been enduring the worst mass bleaching event on record as oceans reach record high temperatures. Coral reefs are an essential habitat for marine species, vital for food security, contribute trillions to the global economy and buffer coastal areas from storms. Global warming is all but certain to breach the globally agreed goal of limiting warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: World's coral reefs crossing survival limit, global experts warn
articles.author: RFI
articles.summary: The world's tropical coral reefs have almost certainly crossed a point of no return as oceans warm beyond a level most can survive. It is the first time scientists have declared that Earth has likely reached a so-called "tipping point" – a shift that could trigger massive and permanent changes in the natural world.

articles.title: World's coral reefs crossing survival limit: global experts
articles.author: e NCA
articles.summary: The world's tropical coral reefs have almost certainly crossed a tipping point as oceans warm beyond a level most can survive, according to a major scientific report. It is the first time scientists have declared that Earth has likely reached a so-called "tipping point" - a shift that could trigger massive changes in the natural world.

articles.title: Good Vs Bad Science (Models) & How You Can Tell The Difference: Think Twice Science
articles.author: William M Briggs
articles.summary: Last time at Think Twice Science we discussed bad models and the bad predictions which arise from them. Not all models are bad, even though it is tempting to believe so. How can you tell a good from bad model? Some of the time it is simplicity itself. You can apply these methods to the models that best you in daily life.

articles.title: Statement by the Nordic and Caribbean Community (CARICOM) Foreign Ministers
articles.summary: Nordic and CARICOM foreign ministers reaffirm their commitment to tackling climate change and finding joint solutions for climate change mitigation and adaptation. They urge the international community to take concrete actions to keep the goal of 1.5 alive at COP 30 to be held in Brazil in November 2025.

articles.title: Behind closed doors
articles.summary: Major mining companies lobbied the Prime Minister in a bid to weaken planned environmental protections. The government announced a reform of the Freedom of Information Act. The changes include a dramatic expansion of excuses to keep documents secret and the charging of new fees. Since landmark reforms in 2010, the FOI regime has fallen into disrepair.

articles.title: For the First Time, We Linked a New Fossil Fuel Project to Hundreds of Deaths. Here's the Impact of Woodside's Scarborough Gas Project
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Global warming from Woodside's massive Scarborough gas project off Western Australia would lead to 484 additional heat-related deaths in Europe alone this century, and kill about 16 million additional corals on the Great Barrier Reef during each future mass bleaching event. The findings were made possible by a formula that can determine the extent of global warming.

articles.title: World crosses first major climate tipping point with coral reef collapse
articles.author: Stuti Mishra
articles.summary: Global Tipping Points Report warns that Earth has passed its first major climate tipping point with the widespread collapse of warm-water coral reefs already underway. The report was produced by 160 scientists from 87 institutions in 23 countries and released ahead of next year's Cop30 climate summit in Brazil. It warns that humanity is now 'dangerously close to triggering further catastrophic thresholds, including the melting of polar ice sheets, the collapse of key ocean currents and the dieback of the Amazon rainforest.

articles.title: Emissions linked to Woodside's Scarborough gas project could lead to at least 480 deaths, research suggests
articles.author: Donna Lu
articles.summary: Greenhouse emissions linked to a gas field being developed by Australian fossil fuel company Woodside could lead to the death of at least 480 people and expose more than half a million to unprecedented heat. The $16.5bn Scarborough project is expected to start production off the northern Western Australian coast next year and could result in 876m tonnes of carbon dioxide being released into the atmosphere over three decades. Woodside says it will reduce the project's direct greenhouse gas emissions to as low as possible.

articles.title: ANU report puts a number on climate impact of Woodside's $19b Scarborough gas project
articles.author: Holly Thompson
articles.summary: Woodside's $18.9 billion Scarborough gas project off WA's coast is directly quantifying a project's climate impact for the first time. The study directly attributed nearly 0.0004 degrees of additional global warming to the project's at least 31 years of emissions from 2026. Lead author Professor Sarah Perkins-Kirkpatrick said the consequences would be great.

articles.title: ANU report puts a number on climate impact of Woodside's $19b Scarborough gas project
articles.author: Holly Thompson
articles.summary: Woodside's $18.9 billion Scarborough gas project off WA's coast is directly quantifying a project's climate impact for the first time. The study directly attributed nearly 0.0004 degrees of additional global warming to the project's at least 31 years of emissions from 2026.

articles.title: Climate tipping points are being crossed, scientists warn ahead of COP30  Oct. 13, 2025 08:48
articles.summary: Global warming is crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected. The world's coral reefs are in an irreversible die-off. The last two years were Earth's warmest on record. Renewables accounted for more electricity generation than coal this year for the first time. Scientists urge countries to work toward bringing down climate-warming carbon emissions.

articles.title: A point of no return on climate
articles.summary: First climate tipping point reached after coral reef diebacks, scientists warn. The world is also approaching further catastrophic tipping points for ice melt, Amazon rainforest dieback and vital ocean currents as it nears the key milestone of 1.5C warming above pre-industrial levels. However, momentum is building towards 'positive tipping points' as countries invest in green technologies.

articles.title: Comment: Charts' trend lines give lie to climate deniers' claims
articles.author: Mark Gongloff
articles.summary: Zeke Hausfather, a climate scientist at Berkeley Earth, produced a chart showing the percentage of the world's land that has experienced its hottest month on record in each decade since the 1870s. Since the 1970s, the average global surface temperature has risen steadily, hitting 1.3 degrees Celsius above the 1951-1980 average.

articles.title: Arctic seals near extinction, global bird population in decline
articles.summary: IUCN's Red List of Threatened Species highlights the danger of the extinction of Arctic seals and the decline of the global bird population due to climate change, deforestation, and agricultural expansion. Scientists believe the Earth has already gone through five mass extinction events and many fear that we are already in the midst of a sixth.

articles.title: Weekly Climate and Energy News Roundup #661
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: This week's TWTW discusses what is meant when a greenhouse gas is said to be saturated. TWTW presents an essay by Steven Koonin on political conformity in the reports by National Academies on climate and concludes with a report on the biases demonstrated by internet search engines.

articles.title: Pirate Attacks on Nigerian Fishers and Traders: A Cycle of Violence and Neglect
articles.author: Premium Timesng
articles.summary: Artisanal fishers and women traders in Nigeria's coastal communities are being targeted by pirates. The primary targets of the attacks are artisanal Fishers and Women Traders, whose livelihoods are already vulnerable due to climate change and dwindling fish stocks. The lack of effective response from authorities and the ongoing violence are devastating coastal communities.

articles.title: Earth crosses first-ever critical climate threshold, scientists warn
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: The report titled 'Global Tipping Points' published by the University of Exeter has reported that Earth has reached its first climate tipping point. The world's warm-water coral reefs are crossing their survival limit with no point of return, declared by the scientists for the first time.

articles.title: World Nears Climate ‘Tipping Point'
articles.author: Admin 365
articles.summary: Global coral reefs are in an irreversible die-off due to human-induced climate change, according to the Global Tipping Points Report released Monday. The report revises the danger threshold for the Amazon rainforest, warning that even 1.5°C of warming could trigger a collapse in the forest ecosystem. Renewable energy sources outpaced coal for electricity generation globally this year.

articles.title: Why Trump is not a death knell for global climate action
articles.summary: Donald Trump called climate change 'the greatest con job ever perpetrated on the world' in a speech to the United Nations last month. Trump supports the US fossil fuel sector and wants to open up 13 million acres of federal land for coal mining. He has ordered the removal of climate data from government sites and eliminated direct government funding for climate science research and monitoring. Trump's initiatives are likely to mean an additional 7 billion tonnes of emissions compared to a scenario where the US met its Paris commitments. It bodes well for international climate action.

articles.title: Kenya: Experts Warn of Rising Mental Health Crisis Linked to Climate Change
articles.author: All Africa
articles.summary: Climate change is increasingly emerging as a public health concern. Researchers warn that its effects are triggering a silent mental health crisis across Kenya.    in Nairobi.  in Mombasa  in Kibera  in ombi  in Kenya.

articles.title: How do you even birdwatch? A comedian and birdwatching champion explain – video
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: BirdLife's Sean Dooley and comedian Geraldine Hickey talk to Matilda Boseley about birdwatching. They discuss the ins and outs of birdwatching and how to get started.    "It's the cure-all to gen Z and millennial woes."

articles.title: World reaches first climate tipping point as scientists issue urgent warning
articles.author: Rebecca Speare-Cole
articles.summary: The planet has crossed its initial climate tipping point, according to a new report. Global warming is now causing widespread diebacks of warm-water coral reefs. The Amazon rainforest could pass its tipping point before the world hits 2C warming. The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) faces collapse sooner than previously thought.

articles.title: Catalonia & Ibiza Floods: Storm Alice Impact 🌊
articles.summary: Storm Alice unleashed torrential rains and devastating floods across northeastern Spain and the Balearic Islands this past weekend. The Ebro Delta, a vital agricultural region, is particularly vulnerable. The past decade was the warmest on record, and this trend is projected to continue. We need to shift from reactive disaster response to proactive risk management.

articles.title: Climate change ushers in 'new reality' as world reaches first tipping point
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: The Second Global Tipping Points Report warns that humanity has reached its first climate tipping point. The report was published ahead of COP30, the annual United Nations climate talks, slated to take place in Brazil this year. The world is close to other irreversible thresholds, such as melting polar ice sheets, the collapse of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation, and the natural death of the Amazon rainforest.

articles.title: Climate, Energy Department Spends Over $1 Million Sending Officials Overseas in 2 Months
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: Australia's Department of Climate Change, Energy, Environment and Water has spent over $1 million sending officials abroad in the first two months of the 2025-26 fiscal year. At a recent Supplementary Budget Estimates, the department has spent US$655,000.

articles.title: Rising heat, drought and floods push food systems to the brink
articles.author: CO-EDP
articles.summary: A new study shows how environmental stressors driven by climate change threaten the stability of food supply chains across three districts in Uttarakhand, India. Rudraprayag, Udham Singh Nagar and Almora are the most vulnerable districts. The authors advocate for an integrated climate response that connects environmental monitoring, digitalization and local intervention priorities.

articles.title: Climate tipping points sound scary, especially for ice sheets and oceans – here's why there's still room for optimism
articles.author: Alexandra A Phillips
articles.summary: As the planet warms, it risks crossing catastrophic tipping points, where Earth systems, such as ice sheets and rain forests, change irreversibly over human lifetimes. Geoscientist who studied the ocean and climate for over a decade and spent a year on Capitol Hill working on bipartisan climate policy sees room for optimism.

articles.title: Rising heat: Climate change at a crossroads with the nation's future
articles.summary: Climate change is a present and growing crisis that could undermine decades of progress in Uganda. Without decisive mitigation and adaptation strategies, Uganda could see its economic growth shrink by 3.1 percent by 2050. Heat stress alone could reduce labour productivity by 2.4 percent, while climate-related disasters threaten to damage 21 percent of the national electricity network and drive annual road maintenance costs to nearly $26 million (Shs88.8 billion). Uganda has taken commendable steps.

articles.title: What La Niña declaration could mean for Australian weather
articles.author: Sarah Swain4:40pm
articles.summary: La Niña weather pattern could affect Australian weather. According to Weatherzone, the system could bring cloud, rain and cooler temperatures. La Niña is a natural climate pattern marked by cooler than average water temperatures in the equatorial Pacific. El Nino and La Nina influence weather globally.

articles.title: Kenya: Experts Warn of Rising Mental Health Crisis Linked to Climate Change
articles.summary: Climate change is a public health concern in Kenya. Droughts, floods, and rising temperatures are driving up cases of psychological distress, depression, and trauma-related disorders. Rural farmers and pastoralists are disproportionately affected because their livelihoods depend on agriculture and livestock.

articles.title: Why banks in Bangladesh should embed climate risk across their operations
articles.author: Karimul Tuhin
articles.summary: Bangladesh's banking industry is on the frontline of climate change. The recent circular on Sustainability and Climate-related Financial Disclosure Guidelines by the Bangladesh Bank signals a new era in financial supervision. Climate change can no longer be overlooked as merely an environmental issue. Banks need to integrate climate risk management into their core operations, governance and strategy.

articles.title: 'Farmers aren't fools': is Victoria on the brink of its worst fire season?
articles.author: Bryce Eishold
articles.summary: Strong winds have dried out dryland grass crops this early in spring in Central Gippsland. John MacLachlan can't remember a time in his 45 years of farming when it has happened before now.    for the past 45 years.

articles.title: 'Farmers aren't fools': is Victoria on the brink of its worst fire season?
articles.author: Bryce Eishold
articles.summary: Western and south-western farmers say conditions are drier now compared to 12 months ago. John MacLachlan's property received 424 millimetres of rain since the start of the year, 50mm more than the same time last year. CFA chief fire officer Jason Heffernan urges farmers to be prepared for an earlier-than-normal fire season. Bill Lambert, who runs a herd of 250 breeding cows, plans to cut his numbers by 30-40.

articles.title: Trump's Climate Stance: A Turn at the UN May Mark a Game Changer
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: President Trump has dismissed climate change as a 'con job' at the United Nations. His administration's withdrawal from the Paris Agreement and promotion of fossil fuels threatens international efforts to address climate change. However, global momentum towards renewable energy and countries like China taking leadership roles provides cautious optimism for climate action without the US at the helm.

articles.title: Klimatforskare: Korallreven är bortom räddning
articles.author: Sebastian Hagberg
articles.summary: A tipping point is a critical threshold that, when crossed, leads to large, accelerating and often irreversible changes in the climate system. Tipping points exist in ice sheets, mountain glaciers, circulation patterns in the ocean, ecosystems, and the atmosphere. Scientists have identified many elements in climate system which may have tipping points. If tipping points are crossed, they are likely to have severe impacts on human society.

articles.title: Dinosaur Legs Grown On Genetically Modified Chicken Embryos In World First
articles.author: IFL Science
articles.summary: The age of the dinosaurs came to a dramatic close as a huge asteroid impact accelerated them on a path towards extinction. Not all of them died out, however, and those that survived went on to become today's birds. The rest of the article is behind a paywall.

articles.title: First climate ‘tipping point' crossed, scientists warn ahead of Cop30 in Brazil
articles.summary: Coral reefs are in irreversible die-off. Global warming was crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected. The warning came from the Global Tipping Points report by 160 researchers worldwide. The report was released weeks before the Cop30 climate summit being held at the edge of the Amazon rainforest in Brazil.

articles.title: CTV National News: Major migration route giving birders some of the best sights
articles.summary: Allison Bamford reports on the change in bird populations and the best spots to see them migrate south.       .   in CTV National News: Major migration route giving birders some of the best sights.  in  CTV News:

articles.title: The Climate Creed: How Fear Replaced Science
articles.author: Mark Keenan
articles.summary: The modern climate narrative was shaped not by evidence, but by politics. The UN's focus on carbon rather than other pollutants has diverted environmentalism from its original mission into politics. In 2019, more than 2,000 experts signed the Climate Intelligence (CLINTEL) Declaration, stating that there is no climate emergency.

articles.title: Threatened By Damning Climate Future, Women In Leadership Could Save Australias Tourism And Hospitality Sector, Research Finds
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Australia is projected to experience 18 days of extreme heatwaves annually, up from just 4 days currently. There will be a 444 per cent increase in heatwave-related deaths in Sydney alone. Tourism, events and hospitality will all take a hit. Swinburne research suggests appointing women on boards and in management positions in hospitality and tourism firms.

articles.title: Tony Burke Urges to Cool Heads After Senator Threatens to Burn Parliament
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: Tony Burke has called for Australians to bring the political temperature down after former Greens Senator Lidia Thorpe said she would be willing to burn down Parliament at a pro-Palestine rally and Tony Burke wants to bring it down.    for Home Affairs and Cyber Security.

articles.title: Senator Says Anti-Racism Efforts Too Slow Amid Concern of ‘Far-Right' Immigration Marches
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: Greens Senator Mehreen Faruqi says not enough is being done to combat racism in Australia. She is concerned that 'March for Australia' protests are pushing some Australians to the far-right. She spoke at a Senate Estimates hearing that examined the federal government's response to racism.

articles.title: Coral reefs become first environmental system on Earth to pass climate "tipping point," report says
articles.summary: Coral reefs are the first environmental system on Earth to pass a climate "tipping point," leading to widespread diebacks due to rising ocean temperatures. The report highlights that coral reefs support nearly a billion people and are crucial habitats for marine life. Coral bleaching has affected over 80% of global reefs.

articles.title: Scientists make stunning discovery while studying satellite images of Earth: 'Mass changes'
articles.author: Michael Muir
articles.summary: There are 220,000 glaciers that are being lost at an alarming rate. 267 billion tons of glaciers were lost each year between 2000 and 2019, and over 9 trillion tons have melted since 1976. The losses have contributed to a global sea rise of 2 centimeters (0.79 inches) from mountain glaciers.

articles.title: Population balance
articles.author: Aisha Khan
articles.summary: Pakistan's population is growing at 2% per year and there are 240 million people in the country. Population growth and climate change are mutually reinforcing issues that require integrated, bold and inclusive policy responses. The writer is the chief executive of the Civil Society Coalition for Climate Change.

articles.title: Climate tipping points are being crossed, scientists warn ahead of COP30, World News
articles.summary: Global warming is crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected. The world's coral reefs are in an irreversible die-off. The Amazon rainforest system is at risk of collapsing once the average global temperature warms beyond 1.5 degrees Celsius. The last two years were Earth's warmest on record. Renewables accounted for more electricity generation than coal this year.

articles.title: Climate tipping points are being crossed, scientists warn ahead of COP30
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: The Global Tipping Points report by 160 researchers synthesizes groundbreaking science to estimate points of no return. It comes just weeks ahead of this year's COP30 climate summit being held at the edge of the Amazon rainforest in Brazil.   Â

articles.title: Schools shift to remote learning, delay openings amid coastal storm
articles.author: Wway News
articles.summary: Southeastern Community College will be operating on a two-hour delay. Whiteville City Schools will have a remote learning day for students and run on a one hour delay for staff. Columbus County Government offices will open at 10:00 a.m. to allow additional time for road conditions to improve and for crews to assess any overnight impacts. Emereau: Bladen will operate on a 1 hour delay due to the amount of water on the roads.

articles.title: 'Whitie' the Estella magpie confirmed as albino - so what does that mean for the bird? And will it still swoop?
articles.author: Erin Hee
articles.summary: Whitie the albino magpie has been spotted in Boorooma Street in Estella, Wagga. Albinism is a rare hereditary genetic condition that causes reduced production of pigment (colouring). It can impact many different animal species. Whitie is an example of a leucistic magpie (blond) that Mr Robinson saw in Wagga two decades ago. Albino birds may be more sensitive to the sun than normal magpies.

articles.title: Experts warn of communities at high risk for natural disasters: 'Forced to stay exposed'
articles.author: Lily Crowder
articles.summary: Experts warn of communities at high risk for natural disasters: 'Forced to stay exposed' in a changing climate. The effects of rising seas are impacting people around the globe. In the Southern United States, continued flooding is causing devastating effects for coastal inhabitants. In Brazil, increasing water temperatures and siltation in Brazil have caused one coastal town to lose 500 homes.

articles.title: A Japanese Pinot Noir town blessed by climate change now worries about the weather
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: A town in Japan has been blessed by climate change and now worries about the weather because of climate change.    for the Pinot Noir town, which has been affected by the climate change, is worried about its weather. for the town, it is concerned about the wine.

articles.title: In a world on fire, workers get burned
articles.author: Sally Tyler
articles.summary: The year 2024 was the hottest ever since worldwide temperature recording began. The health impacts of extreme heat are rising at a furious pace. 70% of the global workforce is at risk from death or injury because of heat. The WHO and WMO report calls for action to ameliorate the harm. Many states have passed outdoor workplace heat standards.

articles.title: Japan sets new record for latest-ever extremely hot day
articles.author: Mainichi Japan
articles.summary: Temperatures reached 35.0 C in Kimotsuki in Kagoshima Prefecture on Sunday. The previous record was set on Oct. 9, 2013 in Itoigawa, Niigata Prefecture. More than 30 locations logged record October highs.

articles.title: Pauline Hanson incredible secret - and why many Aussies are suddenly throwing their support behind her
articles.author: Pauline Hanson
articles.summary: At 71, One Nation's leader is enjoying a political renaissance. High rates of immigration are fuelling increasing resentment in sections of the Australian community. She claims that her past warnings are unfolding before our very eyes. She is 71 years of age and she is a politician.

articles.title: First climate tipping point reached after coral reef diebacks, scientists warn
articles.author: London Evening Standard
articles.summary: Scientists warn that Earth's systems are rapidly approaching dangerous thresholds as temperatures rise and the climate is getting warmer.    i.e. several of Earth's system are approaching dangerous threshold as the temperature is rising. i.a/b/c/g/g

articles.title: Birding is a heightened state with a strange loss of self. Once you start, it's hard to stop
articles.author: Debbie Lustig
articles.summary: Debbie Lustig is a birdwatcher, writer and occasional wildlife rescuer in Melbourne. She started birding as a distraction when she was battling addiction and mental illness. The more birds she recognised, the more she felt part of the natural world. Birding is not all joy and transcendence, it's important to learn about conservation issues.

articles.title: Why Trump is not a death knell for global climate action
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: Coral reefs, ice sheets and Amazon rainforest approaching a tipping point due to global heating, ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The planet has reached its first catastrophic tipping point unless global warming is reduced to 1.2C 'as fast as possible'. Warm water coral reefs will not remain 'at any meaningful scale', according to a report by 160 scientists from 23 countries from around the world.

articles.title: Corals are disappearing, pushing Earth to its first major ‘tipping point'
articles.author: Grist
articles.summary: There is a global temperature rise happening right now. When a tipping point is reached, an Earth system will change dramatically and it will be self-reinforcing, according to the scientists.    .   "We are no longer talking about future tipping points, we are talking about present tipping points"

articles.title: Human trafficking in Australia hits all-time high
articles.summary: Human trafficking reports have nearly doubled over the past five years, according to new figures from the Australian Federal Police. The figures were released by the AFP on Monday.      Â   in this regard.  in addition to other human trafficking related crimes.

articles.title: 'History to be proud of': Tony Abbott's new book celebrating Australia's history
articles.author: Peter Fegan
articles.summary: Tony Abbott has released a new book celebrating Australia's history and how the nation came to be. He feels there's been a lot of negativity and says Australia has lost its way. He reminds people that the invasion wasn't the whole story and that the 26th of January is a date of shame.

articles.title: Climate tipping points being crossed, scientists warn
articles.summary: Global warming is crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected. The world's coral reefs are in an irreversible die-off. This is the first "tipping point" in climate-driven ecosystem collapse. The warning comes ahead of this year's COP30 climate summit being held at the edge of the Amazon rainforest in Brazil.

articles.title: Climate tipping points being crossed, scientists warn
articles.author: Alison Withers
articles.summary: The Global Tipping Points report by 160 researchers synthesises groundbreaking science to estimate points of no return. It comes ahead of this year's COP30 climate summit being held at the edge of the Amazon rainforest in Brazil in November. It's an annual gathering of nations to combat human-induced climate change.

articles.title: Climate tipping points being crossed, scientists warn
articles.author: Alison Withers
articles.summary: The world's coral reefs are in an irreversible die-off. This is the first "tipping point" in climate-driven ecosystem collapse, according to scientists. Global warming is crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected, as scientists say.   .

articles.title: Climate tipping points being crossed, scientists warn
articles.author: Alison Withers
articles.summary: Global warming is crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected, according to the Global Tipping Points report by 160 researchers. The report comes ahead of this year's COP30 climate summit being held at the edge of the Amazon rainforest in Brazil in November. The last two years were earth's warmest on record, with marine heatwaves that stressed 84% of the world's coral reefs to the point of bleaching and, in some cases, death. For corals to recover, the world would need to drastically ramp up climate action to reverse temperatures back down to one degree above the pre-industrial average.

articles.title: World's coral reefs crossing survival limit: global experts
articles.author: Nick Perry AFP
articles.summary: The world's tropical coral reefs have almost certainly crossed a point of no return as oceans warm beyond a level most can survive, according to a major scientific report. It is the first time scientists have declared that Earth has likely reached a so-called "tipping point"

articles.title: World's coral reefs crossing survival limit: global experts
articles.author: Nick Perry Afp
articles.summary: Coral reefs are sensitive to changing conditions in the oceans. Global warming poses the greatest threat to these vibrant ecosystems, according to the scientists.       .   for confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or click here for details.

articles.title: World's coral reefs crossing survival limit: global experts
articles.author: Nick Perry AFP
articles.summary: The world's tropical coral reefs have almost certainly crossed a point of no return as oceans warm beyond a level most can survive, according to a major scientific report. It is the first time scientists have declared that Earth has likely reached a so-called "tipping point"

articles.title: La Niña confirmed; more rain, floods
articles.author: The Philippine Star
articles.summary: La Niña conditions in the tropical Pacific have been confirmed by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA). The agency warns of above-normal rainfall and heightened risks of flooding and landslides in the coming months. La Niña is declared when the monthly sea surface temperature anomaly falls to -0.5°C.

articles.title: Climate tipping points are being crossed, scientists warn ahead of COP30
articles.author: The Star
articles.summary: Global warming is crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected, according to the UNFCCC. It's dangerous because of the rising sea levels. It could be dangerous in the future, too, if it doesn't get better soon.    in the near future.

articles.title: Climate Week 1
articles.author: Napa Valley Register
articles.summary: Linda Brown is at the Global Heat Reduction Initiative booth during the Climate Week NYC event. She is with colleagues at their booth. They are promoting the initiative's global warming goals.       for Linda Brown and her colleagues. For more information visit climateweek.org.

articles.title: Global warming is crossing dangerous thresholds sooner, scientists warn
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: The world's coral reefs are in an irreversible die-off. Global warming was crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected, according to scientists on Monday. The coral reefs in the world are dying off at an almost irreversible rate due to global warming, they said.

articles.title: Tanzania turns to agroforestry amid worsening climate change
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: The effects of climate change are visible in southern Tanzania–s Mbarali region. Once-thriving rice fields now lie cracked and barren. Families are forced to sell livestock to afford the crops.       in Menafn.

articles.title: 9 out of 10 people think protecting forests is critical. Here's what you can do to stop forest destruction! (Greenpeace International)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: A global public poll shows that 86% of people believe that protecting forests is critical in the fight against climate change and 82% want their governments to take more action on this issue. The poll is based on a survey of more than 1,000 people around the world.

articles.title: New Report Finds One of Earth's Most Precious Ecosystems Has Already Crossed a Scary Climate ...
articles.author: Gizmodo
articles.summary: The 2025 Global Tipping Points Report finds that the world's warm-water coral reefs have become the first Earth system to cross its thermal tipping point, putting them at dire risk. The report is based on the World's Warm-water Coral Reefs Report.

articles.title: Climate tipping points sound scary, especially for ice sheets and oceans—why there's still room for optimism
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: As the planet warms, it risks crossing catastrophic tipping points. Scientists have long warned that if global temperatures warmed more than 1.5°C (2.7°F) compared with before the Industrial Revolution, Earth systems such as ice sheets and rainforests could change irreversibly over human lifetimes.

articles.title: Coral reefs are at a tipping point after surging global temperatures
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Record-breaking ocean temperatures have caused widespread bleaching and death among warm-water corals. The bleaching could have far-reaching consequences for the corals' health.       in this way, it could have a serious impact on the environment.

articles.title: 6 common winter habits that could be affecting your health and how to stay safe
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: As temperatures fall, seeking warmth and comfort becomes second nature. Winter routines revolve around cosy indulgences, such as sipping hot cocoa by the fire and staying close to space heaters. Clever Dude report reveals that some common winter practices may quietly affect your health.

articles.title: The world is getting darker. And Leon's getting larger
articles.summary: Global warming is happening at 3.5 W/m^2 on a global average basis. Albedo change results in shifts of 100 W/ m^2, right where more melting will do the most damage. Reducing atmospheric CO2 doesn't fix climate change.

articles.title: Washington state officials take stock as wildfire season winds down
articles.author: Emily Fitzgerald
articles.summary: There were 251,840 acres burned in Washington state and 1,851 documented ignitions as of Oct. 10. The Labor Mountain fire and the Lower Sugarloaf fire in Central Washington are partially contained. The Bear Gulch fire in the Olympic National Forest is still burning. The Department of Fish and Wildlife will conduct prescribed burns on the lands it manages in Eastern Washington. Public Lands Commissioner Dave Upthegrove is asking for $44.8 million for wildfire fighting for the 2026 fiscal year.
